results.title: Plan 9 from outer space = Grave robbers from outer space
results.creator_credit: Edward Wood Jr and Reynolds Pictures
results.brief_description: The local authorities join forces with the military to ward off an invasion of flying saucers. Undeterred, the aliens continue their attempt to conquer Earth by resurrecting corpses from a San Fernando cemetery. “Plan 9 from outer space” has been described as the worst film ever made. This dubious honour has led to the cult status and notoriety the film enjoys to this day, proving that any publicity is good publicity. Those who have seen Tim Burton’s homage, “Ed Wood”, will enjoy seeing this original masterpiece. Bela Lugosi played the definitive vampire as Count Dracula in Tod Browning’s 1931 classic horror. In “Plan 9”, he revives his ghoulish persona in this, his final screen role.

results.title: Plains people
results.brief_description: Contrasts the life styles of the Masai of Kenya and the cowboys of Montana. Shows the Masai’s dependence on the land, use of cattle and division of labour. A brief segment on the cowboys shows a cattle roundup. No other credits available.

results.title: Plain sailing
results.creator_credit: Martin Cohen, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Designed to assist the small businessman by emphasising the necessity of a thorough knowledge and planning before embarking on a business venture. Describes some of the do’s and don’ts that can make or break a business.

results.title: Plagued. Episodes 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Edward Goldwyn, Janet Bell, Deanne Edwards, Channel Four, Goldwyn Associates and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Invisible armies examines infectious diseases and how they have been carried around the world as cultures come into contact with each other, and also how some previously eliminated diseases, such as measles and TB, are making a comeback in the western world because of carelessness about immunisation programs. Diseases discussed include syphilis, malaria and smallpox. “Will we ever learn?” Never before have we had such powerful weapons against disease but the tendency to depend on them too much has led to a philosophy of cure rather than prevention. The program looks at AIDS, syphilis and diseases associated with tobacco use and salt. Norman Swan wrote and narrates this thought provoking series, which contends that the real causes of epidemics are social forces.

results.title: Plagued. Episodes 1 & 2 (A)
results.creator_credit: Edward Goldwyn, Aviva Ziegler, Deanne Edwards, Janet Bell, Channel Four, Film Australia and Goldwyn Associates
results.brief_description: Conceived, written and narrated by award winning medical broadcaster, Dr. Norman Swan, this four part series investigates the relationship between history, destiny and disease. “The Origins of disease” investigates, through various case studies, including Korean haemorrhagic fever, shell shock, RSI and heart disease, how new diseases arise. We also discover that some are not diseases at all, but suffering made worse by factors as diverse as medical jargon and management style. “Epidemics: products of progress” takes up the theme that, ironically, throughout history, epidemics have been the results of so-called progress, and that despite medical technology, we are still vulnerable to old and new diseases, such as plague, cholera and AIDS which have the power to change the course of history.

results.title: Placido: a year in the life of Placido Domingo
results.creator_credit: Revel Guest, Group W, Channel 4 and Transatlantic Films
results.brief_description: Documentary made for television portraying a year in the life of one of the greatest opera singers of our time, Placido Domingo. This charming and charismatic performer takes us on a journey around the world from the major opera houses such as the Royal Opera House Covent Garden and La Scala Milan, to the Metropolitan Opera House in New York. He also manages to include appearances on television shows with Carol Burnett in Los Angeles and Charles Aznavour in Paris. The film includes excerpts from his performances in Tosca, The Tales of Hoffmann, Ernani, Otello, La fanciulla del West, Manon Lescaut and the Zeffirelli film of La Traviata. Also features Dame Kiri te Kanawa in Die Fledermaus.

results.title: Places people live: the family farm
results.creator_credit: Richard S. Jackson and William Claiborne Incorporated
results.brief_description: Contrasts the way of life on small farms in Denmark and Yugoslavia. The Danish farm is highly mechanised and we are shown jobs, animals and buildings. In Yugoslavia, the farm is smaller, unmechanised and involves different activities. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Places people live: seacoast people
results.creator_credit: William L. Claiborne and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: Depicts a day in the life of a lobster fisherman in York Harbor, Maine. Shows the similar methods of harvesting coastal waters used by a Norwegian crab fisherman. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
